extracted_ttps.description: The attackers used a novel PowerShell backdoor, dubbed PowerLess, which runs in a .NET context to evade detection and executes PowerShell code without spawning 'powershell.exe'
The attackers encoded data, including keystrokes and browser information, for exfiltration
The attackers modified the registry to maintain persistence
Detected PowerShell activity via NLP pattern matching
The attackers used social engineering tactics to trick users into executing the malicious PowerShell code
The attackers collected data from the local system, including browser information and keystrokes
Detected Scheduled Task/Job activity via NLP pattern matching
The attackers transferred tools into the network, including the PowerLess backdoor
Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
The attackers used remote services to move laterally within the network
The attackers gathered system information, including the operating system and architecture
The attackers scanned the network for open services and vulnerabilities
Detected Input Capture activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Obfuscated Files or Information activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Exfiltration Over C2 Channel activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Exploit Public-Facing Application activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Network Service Discovery activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Registry Run Keys activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Remote Desktop Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Phishing activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Detect PowerShell Backdoor Execution via .NET Host (PowerLess)
rules.description: Detects execution of PowerShell code by a .NET based backdoor (PowerLess) that does not spawn powershell.exe, using indicators such as a custom WindowsProcesses.exe process, loading of dll.dll, and encoded PowerShell commands.

detection.condition: (selection_suspicious_process or selection_dll_load or selection_ps_code) and not exclude_office

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that use -EncodedCommand with PowerShell.
Authorized .NET applications that load dll.dll as part of normal operation.
Custom internal tools named WindowsProcesses.exe that may include PowerLess as a benign component.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Detection: Data Encoding
rules.description: The attackers encoded data, including keystrokes and browser information, for exfiltration
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Ingress Tool Transfer - Execution of Known Malicious Tool Names
rules.description: Detects execution of processes whose executable name matches known tool indicators associated with Ingress Tool Transfer (PowerLess, WindowsProcesses.exe, dll.dll).

detection.condition: (selection_powerless or selection_windowsprocesses or selection_dll) and not exclusion

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative tools named WindowsProcesses.exe used by IT staff
Custom DLL named dll.dll used by internal applications
Scripts or utilities that contain the string 'PowerLess' in benign contexts

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious Use of Application Layer Protocol Utilities for Potential C2
rules.description: Detects processes that use common networking utilities (PowerShell, bitsadmin, curl, wget, Python) with command‑line arguments indicative of HTTP/HTTPS communication, which may indicate Application Layer Protocol C2 activity.

detection.condition: selection_ps_web or selection_ps_http or selection_ps_https or selection_bits or selection_curl or selection_wget or selection_python_requests

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using PowerShell to download updates or packages.
Bitsadmin used by IT staff for legitimate file transfers.
Developers invoking curl or wget for testing or fetching resources.
Python scripts that import the requests library for internal API calls.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Remote Services Lateral Movement via ProxyShell or Log4j Exploits
rules.description: Detects processes that combine a ProxyShell or Log4j exploit indicator with the use of WinRM for remote service execution, indicating potential lateral movement.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative use of WinRM without an associated exploit
Developers testing Java applications that include the string "log4j" in command line arguments
Security teams running PowerShell scripts that reference "ProxyShell" for research or testing

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious System Information Discovery via WindowsProcesses.exe or DLL Load
rules.description: Detects execution of WindowsProcesses.exe or command lines containing dll.dll, which are indicative of attempts to gather system information. Excludes common system binaries to limit false positives.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that load dll.dll for valid purposes
Internal tools named WindowsProcesses.exe used by IT staff

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Obfuscated Files or Information via Suspicious Command-Line Flags
rules.description: Detects execution of processes with command line arguments indicative of obfuscation techniques such as Base64‑encoded PowerShell commands, certutil decoding, rundll32 DLL execution, or mshta JavaScript execution.

detection.condition: selection_ps_enc or selection_ps_encoded or selection_cert_decode or selection_rundll or selection_mshta_js

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that use PowerShell -EncodedCommand for deployment
System maintenance tools that invoke certutil for legitimate decoding tasks
Software installers that use rundll32.exe to load DLLs
Custom automation that employs mshta.exe for HTML/JS rendering

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Potential Exfiltration Over C2 Channel via System Utilities
rules.description: Detects execution of common Windows utilities with command‑line arguments indicative of data exfiltration over a C2 channel, such as PowerShell Invoke‑WebRequest, bitsadmin transfers, certutil URL cache usage, and encoded PowerShell commands.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that download updates or certificates using bitsadmin or certutil.
PowerShell scripts used by IT for software deployment that include Invoke-WebRequest or Invoke-RestMethod.
System maintenance tasks run under the SYSTEM account that invoke these utilities.

rules.title: Archive Collected Data via Compression Tools
rules.description: Detects use of common archiving utilities and PowerShell Compress-Archive to create archives of collected data, indicating potential data staging for exfiltration.

detection.condition: 1 of archiver_exe, powershell_compress, tar_exe, zip_exe, gzip_exe and not exclude_legit

falsepositives: Legitimate backup scripts or scheduled tasks that use 7z, tar, zip, or gzip for archiving data.
System administrators manually creating archives for maintenance.
Automated software installers that package files using compression utilities.

attacks.description: Basic command to test PowerShell execution without spawning powershell.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints 'Hello, World!' to the console

attacks.description: Intermediate command to demonstrate executing .NET code via PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a message box with 'Test Message'

attacks.command: powershell -Command "& {$tempPath = '$env:TEMP\test.txt'; Set-Content -Path $tempPath -Value 'Test file content' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Start-Process notepad -ArgumentList $tempPath}"
attacks.description: Advanced command to create a file in the temp directory, write to it, and then open it with Notepad, demonstrating file operations and process execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a test file in the temp directory, writes 'Test file content' to it, and opens the file with Notepad

attacks.description: Basic example of encoding a string using PowerShell's ConvertTo-SecureString and ConvertFrom-SecureString cmdlets.
attacks.expected_behavior: Encodes 'Hello World' to a secure string and then converts it back to plaintext, demonstrating basic encoding and decoding capability.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "'Test String' | Set-Content -Path '$env:TEMP\encoded.txt' -Encoding UTF8; Get-Content -Path '$env:TEMP\encoded.txt' -Encoding UTF8 | Set-Content -Path '$env:TEMP\decoded.txt' -Encoding UTF8"
attacks.description: Intermediate example showing how to encode a string to a file and then decode it from the file using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes 'Test String' to a file named encoded.txt in %TEMP%, and then reads from this file to write the decoded string to decoded.txt, demonstrating file-based encoding and decoding.

attacks.description: Advanced example using Base64 encoding to encode a string, save it to a file, and then decode it back to plaintext.
attacks.expected_behavior: Encodes 'Advanced Encoding' to Base64, saves it to a file, reads the file, decodes the Base64 string back to UTF8, and prints the decoded string, demonstrating advanced encoding and decoding techniques.

attacks.description: Encode the authentication log using Base64 and store the result in /tmp.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/auth.log.b64 containing the Base64 representation of /var/log/auth.log.

attacks.description: Compress Firefox's places.sqlite (browser history) with gzip via tar and encode the compressed stream in Base64.
attacks.expected_behavior: Produces /tmp/firefox_places.b64 containing compressed and Base64‑encoded browser history data.

attacks.description: Encrypt the shadow password file with AES‑256‑CBC using OpenSSL and then Base64‑encode the ciphertext for exfiltration.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/shadow_enc.b64 containing the encrypted and Base64‑encoded contents of /etc/shadow.

attacks.description: Adds a new registry key to the Run section, which will execute cmd.exe on startup.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will add a new key to the registry, which will cause cmd.exe to run at startup.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to add a new registry key to the Run section, similar to the first command but utilizing PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command will achieve the same result as the first command but uses PowerShell instead of the reg command.

attacks.description: Adds a registry key that points to a fictional executable in the AppData directory, demonstrating how an attacker might use a user's own directories for persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command modifies the registry to point to a non-existent executable in the user's AppData directory, showcasing a method an attacker might use for persistence without needing admin privileges.

attacks.description: Basic example of modifying a system configuration file by appending a test string. This command does not require root privileges if the file is writable by the user.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new line with 'test_string' will be added to /etc/test.conf, demonstrating modification of a system file.

attacks.description: Intermediate example requiring root privileges to modify a critical system file (/etc/hosts) by appending a test string.
attacks.expected_behavior: The string 'test_string' will be appended to /etc/hosts, showing how an attacker could modify system files for persistence or other malicious purposes.

attacks.description: Advanced example using sed to replace an existing string ('old_string') with 'test_string' in /etc/test.conf, demonstrating a more sophisticated modification of system configuration files.
attacks.expected_behavior: All occurrences of 'old_string' in /etc/test.conf will be replaced with 'test_string', illustrating how an attacker might stealthily modify system files for malicious purposes.

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to get a list of all running processes on the system.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output a list of running processes to the console.

attacks.description: This command creates a file named test.txt in the temporary directory and writes 'Hello World' to it.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt will be created in the %TEMP% directory with the content 'Hello World'.

attacks.description: This command encodes the string 'Get-Process' to Base64 using UTF-16LE encoding.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the Base64 encoded string of 'Get-Process' to the console.

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to start a new cmd.exe process that creates a test file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file named test.txt will be created in the temp directory with the content 'Hello World!'.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c echo This is a test string > %TEMP%\test2.txt
attacks.description: This command uses the cmd.exe binary to create a new file in the temp directory with a test string.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file named test2.txt will be created in the temp directory with the content 'This is a test string'.

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to compress a test file in the temp directory into a zip archive.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new zip file named test.zip will be created in the temp directory containing the test.txt file.

attacks.description: Basic PowerShell command writing a benign file to /tmp
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/testfile.txt with 'Benign content' using PowerShell

attacks.description: Intermediate script generation and execution via PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates and executes /tmp/test_script.sh via bash, writing test output

attacks.description: Advanced Base64-encoded PowerShell command to write a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/advanced_test.txt with encoded command, simulating payload obfuscation

attacks.description: Collect network configuration information and save it to a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The command collects network configuration information, including IP addresses, subnet masks, and default gateways, and saves it to a file named system_info.txt in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Collect shell folder paths from the registry and save them to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command uses PowerShell to collect shell folder paths from the registry and saves them to a file named shell_folders.txt in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Collect user information, including username, groups, and privileges, and save it to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command collects user information, including the username, groups, and privileges, and saves it to a file named user_info.txt in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Copies the user's Bash command history to a staging directory for later exfiltration.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates $HOME/collected_data if it does not exist and copies .bash_history into it as bash_history.txt.

attacks.command: mkdir -p $HOME/collected_data && sqlite3 $HOME/.config/google-chrome/Default/History "SELECT url, title, datetime(last_visit_time/1000000-11644473600, 'unixepoch') AS visit_time FROM urls ORDER BY last_visit_time DESC LIMIT 100;" > $HOME/collected_data/chrome_history.txt
attacks.description: Extracts the 100 most recent URLs from the Chrome browser history SQLite database.
attacks.expected_behavior: Runs a SQLite query against Chrome's History file and writes the output to chrome_history.txt in the staging directory.

attacks.command: mkdir -p $HOME/collected_data && sudo dd if=/dev/input/event0 bs=256 count=500 of=$HOME/collected_data/keystrokes.bin status=none
attacks.description: Captures a short burst of raw keyboard input events from the first input device, storing them in a binary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: With root privileges, reads 500 blocks of 256 bytes from /dev/input/event0 and saves them to keystrokes.bin for later analysis.

attacks.command: schtasks /create /tn "Test Task" /tr "cmd.exe /c echo Hello World > %TEMP%\test.txt" /sc daily
attacks.description: Create a daily scheduled task that runs cmd.exe and writes to a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A new scheduled task is created and runs daily, writing to a file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Query the scheduled task named "Test Task"
attacks.expected_behavior: The scheduled task named "Test Task" is queried and its details are displayed

attacks.description: Delete the scheduled task named "Test Task" without prompting for confirmation
attacks.expected_behavior: The scheduled task named "Test Task" is deleted without prompting for confirmation

attacks.description: Add user cron job to touch file every minute
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates user-level cron job that touches /tmp/cron_example every minute

attacks.description: Create system-wide cron job as root
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates system cron job in /etc/cron.d that touches /tmp/system_cron_example every minute

attacks.command:
sudo bash -c 'echo -e "[Service]
ExecStart=/usr/bin/touch /tmp/systemd_example
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target" > /etc/systemd/system/testservice.service && echo -e "[Timer]
OnBootSec=5min
OnUnitActiveSec=5min
[Install]
WantedBy=timers.target" > /etc/systemd/system/testservice.timer && systemctl enable testservice.timer && systemctl start testservice.timer'
attacks.description: Create and activate systemd timer/service for persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates systemd service and timer that touches /tmp/systemd_example every 5 minutes after boot

attacks.description: Transfers a benign file from a URL to the temp directory using certutil, simulating tool transfer.
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign file will be downloaded to the temp directory.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to download a benign file from a URL to the temp directory, demonstrating an alternative method of tool transfer.
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign file will be downloaded to the temp directory using PowerShell.

attacks.description: Creates a directory in the AppData folder and then uses curl to download a benign file into it, showing a more complex tool transfer scenario.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new directory will be created in AppData, and the benign file will be downloaded into it.

attacks.description: Basic command to download and execute a hypothetical backdoor using wget
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file named 'backdoor' to /tmp and attempts to execute it with bash

attacks.description: Intermediate command using curl to download, making the backdoor executable, and then executing it
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads the payload silently, saves it as 'backdoor', makes it executable, and then runs it

attacks.description: Advanced command attempting to download a backdoor using both wget and curl, falling back if one fails, and executing it from /dev/shm
attacks.expected_behavior: Tries to download the payload using wget, falls back to curl if wget fails, and then attempts to execute it with bash

attacks.description: Start the Telnet service to demonstrate application layer protocol usage
attacks.expected_behavior: The Telnet service starts, allowing for potential command and control communication

attacks.description: Create a web request using PowerShell to simulate application layer protocol activity
attacks.expected_behavior: A web request is sent to the specified URL, demonstrating application layer protocol usage

attacks.description: Use certutil to download a file from a URL, simulating command and control communication
attacks.expected_behavior: The file is downloaded to the temporary directory, demonstrating application layer protocol usage for potential command and control

attacks.description: Basic HTTP beaconing with timestamp
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends HTTP GET request to example.com with timestamp parameter in User-Agent

attacks.description: Intermediate DNS-based command retrieval
attacks.expected_behavior: Resolves TXT record from test.example.com and executes contents via shell

attacks.description: Advanced bidirectional TCP shell over port 80
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates named pipe and establishes interactive shell channel via netcat on HTTP port

attacks.description: Basic remote command execution via SSH to create a test file on the target host.
attacks.expected_behavior: The SSH client connects to the target host (192.168.1.10) as 'user' and writes the string 'remote test' into /tmp/remote_test.txt on the remote system.

attacks.description: Intermediate lateral movement: copy a benign script to the remote host with SCP and execute it via SSH.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script payload.sh from the local $HOME directory is transferred to /tmp on the remote host, then the remote host runs the script with bash, producing any benign output defined in the script.

attacks.description: Advanced reverse shell using netcat and a named pipe to obtain an interactive shell on the attacker machine.
attacks.expected_behavior: A named pipe /tmp/f is created; its contents are fed to an interactive bash shell whose I/O is piped through netcat to the attacker IP 192.168.1.5 on port 4444. The command runs in the background.

attacks.description: Gather detailed system information including OS version, architecture, and more
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays system information in the command prompt window

attacks.description: Retrieve the version of the Windows operating system
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the Windows version in the command prompt window

attacks.description: Get the operating system architecture
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the OS architecture in the command prompt window

attacks.description: Basic system information discovery using uname
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays operating system name, kernel version, and hardware architecture

attacks.description: Intermediate discovery combining kernel version and architecture
attacks.expected_behavior: Shows detailed kernel information and system architecture

attacks.command: echo 'OS Info:' && cat /etc/os-release && echo '\nArch:' && arch && echo '\nCPU Info:' && head -n 5 /proc/cpuinfo
attacks.description: Advanced multi-source system discovery
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays OS identification data, architecture, and partial CPU information from multiple system files

attacks.description: Scans for open network services and connections
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all active network connections and open ports

attacks.description: Scans for listening TCP connections
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all listening TCP connections

attacks.description: Displays IP configuration and scans for open services
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays IP configuration and lists all network interfaces

attacks.description: Basic TCP SYN scan of local subnet
attacks.expected_behavior: Stealth scan identifying live hosts and open ports using SYN packets

attacks.command: for port in {1..1000}; do nc -zv 192.168.1.10 $port -w 1; done
attacks.description: Intermediate port sweep using netcat
attacks.expected_behavior: Sequential connection attempts to ports 1-1000 on target host

attacks.description: Advanced high-speed port scanning
attacks.expected_behavior: Rapid scanning of all ports across subnet using asynchronous packets

attacks.description: Simulate keyboard input by sending keystrokes to the current window.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will simulate typing 'Hello World' into the currently focused window, demonstrating input capture capability without actually capturing user input.

attacks.command: powershell.exe -Command "[Reflection.Assembly]::LoadWithPartialName('System.Windows.Forms'); $o = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.SendKeys; $o.SendWait('This is a test{ENTER}')"
attacks.description: Utilize Reflection to load the necessary assembly for simulating keyboard input, then send a test string followed by an Enter key press.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command loads the System.Windows.Forms assembly via Reflection and uses it to send a test string and then press the Enter key, simulating more complex user interaction.

attacks.command: powershell.exe -Command "Start-Process notepad.exe; Start-Sleep -s 2; Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; [System.Windows.Forms.SendKeys]::SendWait('Input Capture Test')"
attacks.description: Open Notepad, wait for 2 seconds to ensure it's in focus, then simulate keyboard input to type a test string into Notepad.
attacks.expected_behavior: After opening Notepad and waiting briefly, this command simulates typing 'Input Capture Test' into the Notepad window, demonstrating input capture in a more practical scenario.

attacks.description: Basic input capture using the 'script' utility to record a short interactive session and log typed data.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/input_capture.log containing the transcript of the read prompt and the user‑entered data.

attacks.command: bash -c "stty -echo; printf 'Password: '; read pwd; stty echo; echo; echo $pwd >> /tmp/pwd_capture.txt"
attacks.description: Intermediate capture that disables echo, reads a password silently, and writes the captured password to a temporary log file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prompts for a password without echoing it, then appends the entered password to /tmp/pwd_capture.txt.

attacks.description: Advanced persistent keylogger that runs in the background, continuously logging raw keystrokes from the terminal to a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Starts a background process that writes all characters typed in the current terminal to /tmp/tty_input.log until the process is terminated.

attacks.description: Base64 encode file using certutil and delete original
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates encoded test.enc file in TEMP directory and deletes original test.txt

attacks.description: Execute benign command via Base64-encoded PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints 'test' to console using obfuscated execution method

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo test > %TEMP%\test.txt && certutil -encode %TEMP%\test.txt %TEMP%\test.enc > nul && type %TEMP%\test.enc > %TEMP%\legit.txt:obfuscated && del %TEMP%\test.enc /q && del %TEMP%\test.txt /q"
attacks.description: Hide encoded content in Alternate Data Stream
attacks.expected_behavior: Stores encoded data in NTFS Alternate Data Stream of legit.txt and deletes intermediate files

attacks.description: Creates a script with Base64‑encoded content, decodes it to /tmp/obf.sh, makes it executable, and runs it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script prints "Hello, world!" to the console.

attacks.description: Decodes a Base64 string that contains an echo command and executes it directly via sh -c.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the text "Information demonstration" to the terminal.

attacks.description: Writes a script using hex‑escaped characters, marks it executable, and runs it, demonstrating character‑level obfuscation.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints "Hidden message" to the console.

attacks.description: Encode a test file using certutil to simulate data preparation for exfiltration
attacks.expected_behavior: A test file will be encoded and saved as a new file in the %TEMP% directory

attacks.description: Compress a test file to simulate data preparation for exfiltration over a C2 channel
attacks.expected_behavior: A test file will be compressed into a ZIP archive in the %TEMP% directory

attacks.description: Create a file with test data to simulate exfiltration over a C2 channel
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file containing test data will be created in the %TEMP% directory

attacks.description: Basic exfiltration: uses netcat to send the contents of /etc/hostname to a remote listener on IP 192.0.2.10 port 4444.
attacks.expected_behavior: The remote netcat listener receives the hostname string and displays it on its console.

attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration: compresses /etc/passwd with tar/gzip and streams the archive over netcat to the attacker.
attacks.expected_behavior: The remote listener receives a gzipped tar stream containing the passwd file, which can be saved and decompressed for analysis.

attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration: creates a compressed archive of the user's .ssh directory and transfers it over an encrypted SSH session to the attacker, writing it to a timestamped file on the remote host.
attacks.expected_behavior: The attacker’s SSH server stores the received archive at /tmp/exfil_<timestamp>.tar.gz, preserving confidentiality during transit.

attacks.description: Downloads a benign payload from a hypothetical public-facing application and executes it, simulating an exploit.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads and executes a benign payload, testing the detection of public-facing application exploits without causing harm.

attacks.description: Downloads a PowerShell script from a public-facing application and executes it, demonstrating another exploitation vector.
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes a downloaded PowerShell script, simulating the exploitation of a public-facing application via PowerShell.

attacks.description: Creates a benign file and attempts to execute it, testing the detection of exploits that might try to execute arbitrary files.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates and attempts to execute a benign file, simulating an exploit without causing harm.

attacks.description: Basic command injection via HTTP parameter exploiting lack of input sanitization.
attacks.expected_behavior: Web server executes 'id' command and returns user/group info in response.

attacks.description: Intermediate vulnerability check for Apache Struts CVE-2017-5638 exploit.
attacks.expected_behavior: Nmap checks for vulnerable Struts implementation via OGNL injection detection.

attacks.description: Advanced Shellshock exploitation via HTTP header to write test file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Vulnerable CGI script executes bash command, creating /tmp/exploit_test with test content.

attacks.description: Creates a file with test data in the temp directory and then archives it using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip file named 'archived.zip' will be created in the temp directory containing the 'test.txt' file.

attacks.description: Encodes a test file using certutil and then archives the encoded file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip file named 'archived2.zip' will be created in the temp directory containing the encoded 'test.txt' file.

attacks.description: Creates a file with test data using PowerShell and then archives it.
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip file named 'archived3.zip' will be created in the temp directory containing the 'test2.txt' file.

attacks.description: Intermediate archive using zip to compress collected text files into a .zip archive.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/collected_data.zip containing the info.txt file.

attacks.description: Adds a value to the HKCU Run key to execute notepad.exe upon user login, demonstrating user-level persistence without needing admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad will open when the user logs in.

attacks.description: Adds a value to the HKLM Run key to execute notepad.exe upon system startup, demonstrating system-wide persistence requiring admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad will open when the system starts.

attacks.description: Adds a value to the HKCU RunOnce key to execute calc.exe upon the next user login, demonstrating one-time execution without needing admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: Calculator will open once at the next user login.

attacks.description: Appends a malicious command to the rc.local file, which is executed on system startup
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious command will be executed on system startup

attacks.description: Adds a cron job that executes a malicious command at regular intervals
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious command will be executed at regular intervals

attacks.description: Appends a malicious command to the system-wide profile file, which is executed on user login
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious command will be executed on user login

attacks.description: Attempt to establish a Remote Desktop connection to a machine with IP address 192.168.1.100
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will attempt to open a Remote Desktop connection to the specified IP address. If the connection is successful, the user will be prompted for credentials.

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to launch an RDP connection to a machine with IP address 192.168.1.101, demonstrating an alternative method that could be used by an attacker
attacks.expected_behavior: Similar to the first command, this will attempt to establish an RDP connection but uses PowerShell to execute the command, which could be used to evade simple detection mechanisms.

attacks.description: Launch an RDP connection to a machine with IP address 192.168.1.102 using the command prompt, showing another variation of executing RDP
attacks.expected_behavior: This command uses the command prompt to launch the RDP client, connecting to the specified IP address. It's another method an attacker might use to blend in with normal network activity.

attacks.description: Basic RDP client connection using rdesktop to a test server.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to open an RDP session to 192.0.2.1; will display a login window or error message if the host is unreachable or credentials are invalid.

attacks.description: Intermediate RDP connection using the xfreerdp client with certificate validation ignored.
attacks.expected_behavior: Initiates an RDP session to the target IP, ignoring certificate warnings; a graphical login prompt appears or an error is shown if the service is not reachable.

attacks.command: sudo apt-get update -y && sudo apt-get install -y xrdp && sudo systemctl enable --now xrdp
attacks.description: Advanced setup: installs the xrdp service on the local Linux host and starts it, enabling inbound RDP connections.
attacks.expected_behavior: Installs xrdp, enables the service to start at boot, and launches it immediately; the host will now listen on TCP port 3389 for incoming RDP connections.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "& {Write-Host 'You have won a prize, click here to claim: https://example.com'}"
attacks.description: Basic phishing attempt using PowerShell to display a fake prize message
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a fake prize message to the user

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c echo You have won a prize, click here to claim: https://example.com > %TEMP%\phish.txt && start %TEMP%\phish.txt
attacks.description: Intermediate phishing attempt using cmd.exe to create a fake prize message file and open it
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a fake prize message file and opens it in the default text editor

attacks.command: powershell -Command "& {Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; $form = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Form; $form.Text = 'Phishing Alert'; $label = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Label; $label.Text = 'You have won a prize, click here to claim: https://example.com'; $form.Controls.Add($label); $form.ShowDialog()}")
attacks.description: Advanced phishing attempt using PowerShell to create a fake prize message dialog box
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a fake prize message dialog box to the user

attacks.description: Downloads and executes a script under the guise of a legitimate system update
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a benign test script from example.com, makes it executable, and runs it. Simulates initial payload delivery via phishing.

attacks.command: echo "Alert: Account security check required! Enter password:" && read -s password && echo "Captured password: $password" > /tmp/creds.log
attacks.description: Fake security alert prompting user to enter credentials
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays deceptive message and captures user password input to a file without terminal echo.

attacks.command: echo '[!] System Verification Failed' && read -p 'Enter username: ' user && read -s -p 'Enter password: ' pass && echo "$user:$pass" | openssl enc -e -aes256 -out $HOME/.cache/auth_enc.dat -k dummykey
attacks.description: Advanced credential harvesting with local encryption storage
attacks.expected_behavior: Mimics system error to harvest credentials, encrypts them using AES-256, and stores in user cache directory for simulated exfiltration.
